-Coughing Fit

figure I'd pass along some advice before I slink off to bed

I myself did plenty of short stories, narratives, and prose in high school, most of it is trash and unfinished, but I did it for myself and got the practice in, and learned from my mistakes.

Since then I've been DM'ing for a full on campaign, so I've gotten used to thinking in the long term. Pacing is fucking critical to the length of a story, make sure you touch on what events you want to cover and make sure your pace in touching on them is appropriate. Too fast and you lose audience investment. Too slow (like most fucking shonen 500 episodes holy fuck!) and your audience feels like nothing new is going on, or shit is just dragging along wayy too fuckin slow.

I always try to make sure that none of the scenes are wasted, always have a character doing something. Never write filler.

I'll go pass out now

Anonymous Tue 03 Apr 2018 09:07:46 No.14946518 Report
Quoted By: >>14946557
>>14946424
Keep writing, even if it's dumb shit. No, I'm serious. Your brain will go "no, that wouldn't happen" <x> number of times before it finally settles and goes "Okay, fine, that does work." from the sheer amount of process of elimination. That being said, this can be exhausting, so just chisel at it until you break through.

Also, I see it often enough that a creative type isn't 'inspired' or 'motivated' to do their thing. Sucks dick, I know, but (this is all paraphrased from a book on writing I read, by the by) inspiration and motivation are wonderful yet fleeting. They won't always be there when you need them, such as when you have deadlines. You know what can always be there? Discipline. You have to One Punch Man that shit. 1000 words a day. 5 paragraphs every night. 1 entry a week. If you can get yourself to be able to consistently hammer out words, that's a skill that can be trained just like you can train yourself to benchpress 300.

Do you think Stephen King is just -that- creatively motivated that he can churn out twenty books a year? No. The man is a fucking machine with a daily word count that puts entire genres worth of writers to shame.

When it comes to creativity, yeah, learn to take a break every now and then for your own mental health. It can be taxing to come up with something, especially after you've written yourself into a bind. But word count is work ethic and work ethic is word count; don't let some Dobson-esque motherfucker on deviant-art tell you any different.

Anonymous Tue 03 Apr 2018 09:34:43 No.14946704 Report
Quoted By: >>14946775 >>14946800
>>14946516
Because you're agonizing. Don't get me wrong, I agonize over the actual prose in Silver Lining. That's just how I edit. I'll write a paragraph, read it aloud, rewrite, and repeat until I'm happy. Most people seem to draft to much the same end. What I don't do is agonize much over the story. When you set out, you can't realistically know what you have in store. Your characters probably aren't quite who you think they are, or they at least won't stay that way long. There is a role for planning, but don't panic. No plan survives contact with the enemy. For any given chapter of Silver Lining, I usually know what I need to make happen and more or less what's going on, but not how. Take the last chapter of SL. Going in, I knew two things: A&W were going to be doing a bit of snooping, and that they needed to learn something meaningful. I had no idea how any of that was going to happen. Even important character scenes, such as Whitney's helping Anon face his fear of heights, were unplanned. Similarly, I'm never really sure how fast the mystery is moving. I revealed orders of magnitude more about Echo's cargo, intentions, and allegiances in the last chapter than I intended to. When I got into the actual nitty gritty (the fight scene was also totally unplanned), it started to make a lot more sense to say a lot more, and the pacing of the whole story became clearer to me. I accelerated a lot of plans based on that. That's what I mean by write "casually".

If you're stalling because you don't have any more actual material and just feel like there should be more, then you legitimately shouldn't write more. Never write length for lengths sake. Length is weakness. It's allowable in large degrees, but it's weakness. Note the prevalence of the novella and play script in classic literature: Of Mice and Men, Snows of Killamenjaro, The Great Gatsby, Hamlet, etc. Long novels tend to be forgotten. Writing long stories takes some commitment, but not every story is better long.

I think the best thing to do with longer stories is to have a plot be as clear as possible before going in. Set up a series of points you want to hit and expand upon that slowly. The absolute worst thing you can do is not have some sort of defined goal to work towards when you're planning something out. Does that mean do like I do and have literally the entire story save for some flair to add in aready planned? Jesus christ no. But have major plot points already done up in your head to work towards. If you think on it a while and try to think about certain events then you may just end up having small moments of inspiration you didn't expect otherwise.

Anonymous Tue 03 Apr 2018 10:24:08 No.14947084 Report
Quoted By:
>>14946775
The writing world seems very divided on this. My professors have mostly been big on my approach, and it's always worked best for me. We've got a few poster children (Gabriel Garcia Marques, IIRC, among others) but shit seems pretty individual. Like many things, I usually just recommend someone who's struggling do the opposite of what they're doing now.

In my case, I almost never know the whole plot in the beginning. I only think I do. My certainty tends to be fairly exponential with time, though. For reference:
Ch1: had a plan, threw it out
Ch2: had a new context and knew where it needed to go (secret cargo etc)
Ch3: entirely new plan that since hasn't really changed (assorted spoilers)
Ch4/5: a few details that altered the "why" question in a small way, and selected my endgame formally.

I've always had a plan for the "what" and "why", but the original was thrown out entirely by the second chapter. By the third I already had the information that would drive almost every event in the story going forward. The actual act of writing is just better at enforcing logical progression, at least for me. I accept that I will change my main plans early on, and I then plan the what and why, but not the how. I know how Silver Lining will end, and the plot of the story to follow it. I don't know what scars the characters will have when they get there, what they'll know about each other, or what exactly their relationship will look like (other than loving). For comparison, Degeneracy Pressure is/was a lot more structured. Its slow release rate is due in a large part to it's mostly failing to undergo the process I described above, really because I didn't give it room to.
Anonymous

Anonymous Tue 03 Apr 2018 11:00:04 No.14947255 Report
Quoted By: >>14947344
>>14946800
This is actually exactly what I'm talking about. You need the characters to go on a date. Great. What I would do is just put them together with the objective of having one ask the other, and wait for it to happen. If that takes awhile and I end up cutting out trash from the beginning, so be it. If it were my story, I would know A, B, and the setting of A->B, but not the events of A->B. For instance, I might know I need one to ask the other, or even which should ask the other, and that the two will be driving together when I need this to happen. There are a lot of ways it might end up happening. I'd find out which by starting to write the scene in the car. Maybe they get embroiled in a conversation and want to continue it some time. Maybe they get stuck in traffic so goddamn bad they just decide to break for lunch, and have a date accidentally. Maybe it happens then and there over a cling wrapped peanut butter sandwich. It's not important how as long as it makes sense and doesn't seem forced, and you can't force something you don't plan. Start writing the scene, and try to simulate people in it. Base that on what you know. Let's say they are in a car; what experiences do you have with people stuck in a car together? Don't retell one, at least not necessarily, but make characters act the way they act in your memory. A solution will probably present itself. If it doesn't, cut and try again.

An anon falls in love with a lynx anthro.
Unable to confess, he is gifted by a deus ex machina with her phone number. Never minding the strange area code, he calls her, and is overjoyed to find out that she has a crush on him as well.

But the next day, when he recounts the previous day's confession to the girl, she only looks at him with a perplexed experssion. After some investigation, he finds out the girl he called is not the same girl he fell in love with. In fact, she doesn't exist in this universe at all. She is the girl's alternate universe counterpart, who has fallen in love with the MC's own alternate univer self, who too is unaware of her love.

Hijinks ensue as the two strike up a deal to give each other their darkest, most private secrets in order to equip the other with the weapons they need to conquer the heart of their other selves, While the two chase their respective loved ones, DRAMA ensues as the fall in love with each other instead and question the NATURE OF LOVE.

I can see where you're coming from and don't want to just plain crap on your idea but it might not be a good fit for here.
Although the protag would be biologically human, his mind would be that of a wolfboy.
That would mean that, if written from his perspective, the reader would be trying to see this world as he sees it. A wolf in human clothing.
If he gets it on with an anthro for example, his thoughts are surely going to be on how different it is using a human penor compared to his knot rather than marvelling over the exotic beauty of the anthro girl...
Don't get me wrong, it has merit and has potential to be quite a thoughtful piece, but I'm not sure hmofa is the best platform for it.
Just my two cents.
